::: {.unit-overview}
# Overview

Before you can track changes, you need Git on your computer and a few global settings that stamp each commit with your identity.

:::
<!-- end unit-overview div -->

::: {.unit-goals}
# Goals

* Install the latest stable Git on your system.
* Configure your username, email, and default branch name.
* Generate an SSH key and add it to GitHub.
* Verify connectivity to GitHub.

:::
<!-- end unit-goals div -->

::: {.unit-reading}
# Reading

## Install Git

Download Git from <https://git-scm.com/downloads> and install it for your operating system.

- Windows: Use the default installer options unless you know you want a different setup.
- macOS: You can install via the Git website or with Homebrew (`brew install git`).
- Linux: Use your package manager (e.g., `sudo apt install git`).

Confirm installation:

```bash
git --version
```

## Configure identity and defaults

Set your name and email (this is what appears in commit history):

```bash
git config --global user.name "Your Name"
git config --global user.email "you@example.com"
```

Set the default branch name to `main`:

```bash
git config --global init.defaultBranch main
```

## Generate an SSH key and add it to GitHub

SSH keys let you connect to GitHub without re-entering your password.

```bash
ssh-keygen -t ed25519 -C "you@example.com"
```

Then add the public key (usually `~/.ssh/id_ed25519.pub`) to GitHub under:
`Settings → SSH and GPG keys`.

## Test your connection

```bash
git ls-remote git@github.com:octocat/Hello-World.git
```

If you see output and no error, your SSH connection is working.

:::
<!-- end unit-reading div -->


::: {.unit-summary}
# Summary

You installed Git, configured your identity, set a default branch name, and connected to GitHub via SSH. This is the foundation for every Git/GitHub workflow in the course.

:::

::: {.unit-exercise}
# Practice

1. Install Git and confirm `git --version` ≥ 2.40.
2. Set your global username and email.
3. Generate an SSH key and add it to your GitHub account.
4. Clone `git@github.com:octocat/Hello-World.git` to verify SSH access.
5. Change the default editor (`git config --global core.editor "nano"` or similar).

:::
